questions.question: Question 1: When dynamic -motor neurons are activated at the same time as  -motor neurons to muscle,

options.a: Prompt inhibition of discharge in spindle Ia afferents takes place.
options.c: The number of impulses in spindle Ia afferents is smaller than when  discharge alone is
options.d: The number of impulses in spindle Ia afferents is greater than when  discharge alone is

questions.explanation:
When dynamic -motor neurons are activated at the same time as  -motor neurons to muscle, the 
number of impulses in spindle Ia afferents is greater than when  discharge alone is increased. • When  – coactivation occurs, intrafusal and extrafusal fibers shorten together, and spindle 
afferent activity can occur throughout the period of muscle contraction. • Stimulation of -motor neurons causes increase discharge in spindle Ia afferent, leading to reflex 
contraction of the muscle. • When a muscle contracts it leads to shortening of the muscle spindles and so impulses in the Ia 
afferents decreases. • Thus, muscles can be made to contract via stimulation of the  -motor neurons that innervate the 
extrafusal fibers or the -motor neurons that initiate contraction indirectly via the stretch reflex. • If the whole muscle is stretched during stimulation of the -motor neurons, the rate of discharge 
in the Ia fibers is further increased. Increased -motor neuron activity thus increases spindle 
sensitivity during stretch. This is the basis of the Jendrassik manouver. 296

questions.question:
Question 2: The myogram below shows a slow onset and a longer after-discharge. Which type of reflex 
does it represent?
questions.explanation:
The figure shows the typical myogram recorded from a muscle involved in a crossed extensor 
reflex. This myogram demonstrates the relatively long latency before the reflex begins and the 
long after-discharge at the end of the stimulus. • When a painful stimulus is applied to the body, the flexor withdrawal and the crossed extensor 
reflexes are stimulated. • About 0.2 to 0.5 seconds after the flexor reflex in one limb, the opposite limb begins to extend. 
This reflex is called the crossed extensor reflex. • After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has an even longer period of 
after-discharge than does the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from 
reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells. Compare the myograms of a flexor reflex with a crossed extensor reflex. In the flexor reflex, the contraction occurs immediately after applying the stimulus and the 
after-discharge is smaller.

questions.question:
Question 3: The bulboreticular facilitatory area of the brain stem excites the gamma efferent system. This 
bulboreticular area receives impulses from which of the following areas?
questions.explanation:
Impulses are transmitted into the bulboreticular area from • Cerebellum, • Basal ganglia, and • Cerebral cortex. 297 
Sold by @itachibot The gamma efferent system is excited by signals from the bulboreticular facilitatory region of the 
brain stem. When the bulboreticular facilitatory region transmits excitatory signals through the gamma nerve 
fibers to the intrafusal muscle fibers of the muscle spindles, it shortens the ends of the spindles 
and stretches the central receptor regions, thus increasing their signal output. If the spindles on 
both sides of each joint are activated at the same time, then reflex excitation of the skeletal 
muscles on both sides of the joint increases, producing tight, tense muscles opposing each other at 
the joint. The net effect is that the position of the joint becomes strongly stabilized. Any time a person must perform a muscle function that requires a high degree of delicate and 
exact positioning, the bulboreticular facilitatory region of the brain stem stabilizes the positions of 
the proximal joints.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following describes components of the central pathway responsible for control 
of posture?

options.a: The pontine reticulospinal pathway terminates on neurons in the dorsomedial area of the
options.b: The tectospinal pathway terminates on neurons in the dorsolateral area of the spinal ventral
options.c: The medullary reticulospinal pathway terminates on neurons in the ventromedial area of the

questions.explanation:
The medullary reticulospinal pathway terminates on neurons in the ventromedial area of the 
spinal ventral horn, that innervate axial and proximal muscles. The medullary reticular nuclei transmit inhibitory signals to the antigravity anterior motor 
neurons by way of the medullary reticulospinal tract, located in the lateral column of the cord. Option A: The pontine reticular nuclei transmit excitatory signals through the pontine 
reticulospinal tract in the anterior column of the cord. The fibers of this pathway terminate on the 
medial anterior motor neurons that excite the axial muscles of the body, that is the muscles of the 
vertebral column and the extensor muscles of the limbs. Option B: The tectospinal tract originates in the superior colliculus of the midbrain. It projects to 
the contralateral cervical spinal cord to control head and eye movements.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a medial pathway involved in maintenance of posture?
questions.explanation:
The rubrospinal tract is a part of the lateral brainstem pathway. • The medial brainstem pathways : pontine and medullary reticulospinal, vestibulospinal, and 
tectospinal tracts. • These pathways descend in the ipsilateral ventral columns of the spinal cord and terminate 
predominantly on interneurons in the ventromedial part of the ventral horn to control axial and 
proximal muscles. • The lateral brainstem pathways : The corticospinal tract and the rubrospinal tract. • They cross the midline and project to interneurons in the dorsolateral part of the spinal ventral 
horn to also influence motor neurons that control distal limb muscles. • The rubrospinal tract excites flexor motor neurons and inhibits extensor motor neurons. This 
pathway may play a role in the posture typical of decorticate rigidity. 298

questions.question:
Question 6: Increased neural activity before a skilled voluntary movement is first seen in  
.
questions.explanation:
The command for voluntary movement originates in cortical association areas, then planned in 
the cortex as well as in the basal ganglia and the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres. 
Hence, the neural activity first originates in the cortical association areas. The basal ganglia and cerebellum funnel information to the premotor and motor cortex by way of 
the thalamus. Motor commands from the motor cortex are relayed in large part via the corticospinal tracts to the 
spinal cord. • Motor Association Area: Idea about voluntary movement • Basal Ganglia: Planning and Organising the act • Cerebellum( Neocerebellum) - Planning the act • Premotor Cortex: Setting the posture before the act • Primary Motor Cortex: Executing the act • Spinocerebellum : Smoothening the act

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following descending motor tracts is essential for rapid skilled movement?
questions.explanation:
The lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal tracts are concerned with distal limb muscles and, with 
skilled voluntary movements. The ventral corticospinal tract and medial descending brainstem pathways (tectospinal, 
reticulospinal, and vestibulospinal tracts) are concerned with the axial muscles - postural 
adjustments and gross movements. Note: Medial portion of the ventral horn innervate proximal limb muscles, particularly the flexors. 
Lateral ventral horn innervates distal limb muscles. 299

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is true about experimental sham rage?

options.c: Is caused by removing the hypothalamus

questions.explanation:
Sham rage occurs in decorticate animals is the true statement. Sham rage is a controversial term used to describe behavior such as biting, clawing, hissing, 
arching the back and "violent alternating limb movements" produced in animal experiments by 
removing the cerebral cortex, which is claimed to occur in the absence of any sort of inner 
experience of rage. The reason for this might be that the removal of the neocortex causes a loss of inhibition of the 
areas involved in the rage reaction, causing those areas to become hyperactive (due to an 
uninhibited hypothalamus). Removal of hypothalamus abolishes the sham rage. Sham rage may be triggered by very mild stimuli such as weak touch. It is also non-goal directed.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 62-year-old known hypertensive woman presented to the emergency with spasticity of both 
lower limbs. Further neurological examination showed regular, repetitive, rhythmic 
contractions of a muscle subjected to sudden, maintained stretch. Which of the following is 
false regarding this phenomenon?

options.a: Only sustained clonus with five or more beats is considered abnormal
options.b: Clonus may also occur in spinal cord injury that disrupts the descending cortical input to a
options.c: The stretch reflex–inverse stretch reflex sequence may contribute to this response
options.d: This is characteristic of states in which decreased -motor neuron discharge is present

questions.explanation:
The case scenario indicates clonus. A characteristic of states in which increased -motor neuron 
discharge is present is clonus. All the other options are correct. When a muscle is subjected to a sudden and maintained stretch, there occur regular, repetitive, 
and rhythmic contractions. This is called clonus. Ankle clonus is a typical example.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following statements regarding a clasp knife effect is false?
questions.explanation:
Pacinian corpuscle is not involved in the clasp knife effect. • When the muscles are hypertonic, the sequence of moderate stretch leads to muscle contraction, 
strong stretch leads to muscle relaxation. Eg. Passive flexion of the elbow meets immediate 
resistance due to stretch reflex in the triceps muscle. Further stretch activates the inverse stretch 
reflex. The resistance to flexion suddenly collapses, and the arm flexes. This sequence of 
resistance followed by a sudden decrease in resistance when a limb is moved passively is known as 
the clasp-knife effect because of its resemblance to the closing of a pocket knife. • Lengthening reaction: When the tension on the muscle becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect 
from the Golgi tendon organ leads to an instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. It is a 
protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle. 300 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Fill in the blanks: Efferent axons from the dentate nucleus terminate in  
 
thalamic nucleus and travel through  
peduncle?
questions.explanation:
Efferent axons from the dentate nucleus terminate in Ventral lateral nucleus of the thalamus (VL) 
and travel through superior cerebellar peduncle. The cerebellar cortex projects to the deep nuclei, which in turn project to the brainstem. The deep 
nuclei provide the only output for the spinocerebellum and the cerebrocerebellum: • The medial spinocerebellum projects to the fastigial nuclei and from there to the brainstem. • The adjacent hemispheric portions of the spinocerebellum project to the emboliform and globose 
nuclei and from there to the brainstem. • The cerebrocerebellum projects to the dentate nucleus (Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into 
this nucleus) and from there either directly or indirectly to the ventrolateral nucleus of the 
thalamus. These fibres pass through the cerebellar peduncles: • The superior cerebellar peduncle includes fibers from deep cerebellar nuclei that project to the 
brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus. It also contains the ventral spinocerebellar tract fibers. • The middle cerebellar peduncle contains only afferent fibers from the contralateral pontine 
nuclei. • Inferior cerebellar peduncle a mixture of afferent fibers from the brainstem and spinal cord and 
efferent fibers to the vestibular nuclei.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient has developed an inability to control the distance, speed, and range of motion 
necessary to perform smoothly coordinated movements. His finger-to-nose test and 
heel-to-shin tests are abnormal. A lesion in which of the following sites is most likely to be 
found?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical findings are suggestive of dysmetria which is most commonly found due to a 
lesion involving the cerebellum or the cerebellar pathways. Therefore, a lesion in the 
spinocerebellar tract is most likely to be found in this patient. • Dysmetria - In the absence of the cerebellum, the subconscious motor control system cannot 
predict how far movements will go. Therefore, the movements ordinarily overshoot their intended 
mark; then the conscious portion of the brain overcompensates in the opposite direction for the 
succeeding compensatory movement. Dysmetria also results from lesions in the spinocerebellar 
tracts because feedback information from the moving parts of the body to the cerebellum is 
essential for cerebellar timing of movement termination. 302 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: 293 
Sold by @itachibot Dysdiadochokinesia refers to which of the following?

options.a: Inability to perform the Tandem-Gait test
options.b: Inability to stand without swaying with eyes open
options.d: Inability to perform rapid alternating movements with the hands

questions.explanation:
Dysdiadochokinesia—Inability to Perform Rapid Alternating Movements. • In cerebellar lesions, the motor control system fails to predict where the different parts of the 
body will be at a given time. As a result, the succeeding movement may begin much too early or 
much too late and no orderly “progression of movement” can occur. • So, a series of stalled attempted but jumbled movements occurs instead of the normal 
coordinated movements. This condition is called dysdiadochokinesia.

questions.question:
Question 15: The patient exhibited an unsteady "drunk like" gait and the physician noted that he swayed 
while entering the examination room. Which region of the cerebellum was most likely 
affected by the bleed?
questions.explanation:
Flocculonodular Lobe is involved in the unsteady "drunk like" gait of the patient. Cerebellum has three parts based on function. • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): The oldest part of the cerebellum which contains 
nodulus in the vermis and the flanking flocculus. It has vestibular connections and is concerned 
with equilibrium and gait. Loss of it can cause disturbance of equilibrium and postural 
movements, especially during rapid movements. • Spinocerebellum: The region that receives proprioceptive input from the body as well as a copy 
of the “motor plan” from the motor cortex. By comparing the plan with performance, it smooths 
and coordinates movements that are ongoing. Superior vermis is a part of spinocerebellum. Loss 
of it can cause problems with coordination. • Cerebrocerebellum: They are the newest from a phylogenetic point of view, reaching their 
greatest development in humans. They interact with the motor cortex in planning and 
programming movements.

questions.question: Question 16: The efferent fibres of the basal ganglia include which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The two major outputs/ efferents of the basal ganglia are from Globus pallidus interna and 
substantia nigra pars reticulata. Both are inhibitory (GABAergic) and both project to the 
ventrolateral and ventroanterior thalamus. 303

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following describes a connection between components of the basal ganglia?

options.a: The subthalamic nucleus releases glutamate to excite the globus pallidus, internal segment.
options.b: The substantia nigra pars reticulata releases dopamine to excite the globus pallidus, external
options.c: The striatum releases acetylcholine to excite the substantia nigra pars reticulata.
options.d: The globus pallidus, external segment releases glutamate to excite the striatum.

questions.explanation:
Intranuclear Connections: • Dopaminergic nigrostriatal projection from the substantia nigra pars compacta to the striatum. 
GABAergic projection from the striatum to substantia nigra pars reticulata. • There is an inhibitory (GABAergic) projection from the striatum to both GPe and GPi. • The subthalamic nucleus receives an inhibitory input from GPe, and in turn the subthalamic 
nucleus has an excitatory (glutamate) projection to both GPe and GPi. • From the ventrolateral thalamus, there is an excitatory (presumably glutamate) projection to the 
prefrontal and premotor cortex. This completes a full cortical-basal ganglia-thalamic-cortical loop. 304 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is false regarding the functions of basal ganglia ?

options.a: Neurons in the basal ganglia, like those in the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres,
options.b: The putamen circuit has its inputs mainly from the parts of the brain adjacent to the primary
options.c: The caudate nucleus plays a major role in this cognitive control of motor activity.
options.d: Substantia nigra pars reticulata is a major source of dopaminergic neurons to the corpus

questions.explanation:
Substantia nigra pars compacta (not pars reticulata) is the major source of dopaminergic neurons 
to the striatum. Neurons in the basal ganglia, like those in the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres, 
discharge before movements begin since the basal ganglia are involved in the planning and 
organization of skilled movements. • The putamen circuit has its inputs mainly from the parts of the brain adjacent to the primary 
motor cortex. Then its outputs do go mainly back to the primary motor cortex and adjacent 
premotor cortex. it is mainly involved in complex motor activity and skilled movement. • The caudate circuit plays a major role in the cognitive control of motor activity. 305 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: In a patient suffering from parkinsons's disease, what is the most likely reason behind the 
gradual decline in the therapeutic effect of L-dopa?

options.b: Inhibitory pathways grow into the basal ganglia from the frontal lobe.
options.c: There is an increase in circulating  -synuclein.
options.d: The dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra continue to degenerate.

questions.explanation:
The most likely reason behind the gradual decline in the therapeutic effect of L-dopa in a patient 
suffering from parkinsons's disease is the continued degeneration of the dopaminergic neurons in 
the substantia nigra. Since endogenous production of dopamine continues to decline, 
the exogenous source of dopamine (i.e. L-dopa) alone fails to maintain the same level of 
therapeutic effect. • Parkinson's disease (Paralysis Agitans) was shown to result from the degeneration of 
dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta. The fibres to the putamen (part of 
the striatum) are most severely affected. • Dopaminergic neurons and dopamine receptors are steadily lost with age in the basal ganglia in 
healthy individuals, and an acceleration of these losses apparently precipitates parkinsonism. 
Symptoms appear when 60–80% of the nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons degenerate.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 50-year-old gentleman who is a known patient of parkinson's disease, develops 
refractoriness to L-dopa therapy. An alternative treatment modality is being planned, which 
employs ablation of certain thalamic regions by neurosurgery. Which thalamic nucleus is the 
stereotaxic target for the neurosurgeons?
questions.explanation:
The ventrolateral thalamic nucleus is the stereotaxic target for the neurosurgeons to alleviate 
symptoms in Parkinson's disease refractory to levodopa. • The two major outputs of the basal ganglia are from GPi and substantia nigra pars reticulata. 
Both are inhibitory (GABAergic) and both project to the ventrolateral and ventroanterior 
thalamus. From the thalamus, there is an excitatory (presumably glutamate) projection to the 
prefrontal and premotor cortex. This completes a full cortical-basal ganglia-thalamic-cortical loop. Therefore stereotactic ablation of ventrolateral thalamic nucleus helps in alleviation of symptoms 
in parkinson's disease refractory to levodopa. 306
